review.title: On the measure of conflicts: A MUS-Decomposition Based Framework
review.abstract: Measuring inconsistency is viewed as an important issue related to handling inconsistencies. Good measures are supposed to satisfy a set of rational properties. However, defining sound properties is sometimes problematic. In this paper, we emphasize one such property, named Decomposability, rarely discussed in the literature due to its modeling difficulties. To this end, we propose an independent decomposition which is more intuitive than existing proposals. To analyze inconsistency in a more fine-grained way, we introduce a graph representation of a knowledge base and various MUSdecompositions. One particular MUS-decomposition, named distributable MUS-decomposition leads to an interesting partition of inconsistencies in a knowledge base such that multiple experts can check inconsistencies in parallel, which is impossible under existing measures. Such particular MUSdecomposition results in an inconsistency measure that satisfies a number of desired properties. Moreover, we give an upper bound complexity of the measure that can be computed using 0/1 linear programming or Min Cost Satisfiability problems, and conduct preliminary experiments to show its feasibility.

sections.heading: 6.1 Closed Set Packing
sections.text: The Maximum Set Packing Problem is one of the basic optimization problems (see e.g. (Garey and Johnson 1990)) and is related to other known optimization problems, such as the Maximum Independent Set and Maximum Clique Problems (Arora et al. 1998; Arora and Safra 1998; Boppana and Halldo ́ rsson 1992; Feige et al. 1996; Wigderson 1983). Here we present a variant of this problem, the Maximum Closed Set Packing Problem. We show that this variant is NPhard by providing for a reduction in the Maximum Set Packing Problem, which is NP-hard (Karp 1972). In this work, the Maximum Closed Set Packing Problem is used to calculate the distribution-based inconsistency packing problem.

sections.heading: 7 Experimental Results
sections.text: In this section we present a preliminary experimental evaluation of our proposed approach. All experiments were conducted on an Xeon 3.2GHz (2GB RAM) cluster. We performed two types of experiments, the first of which deals with instances derived from the classical MUSes enumeration problem. eMUS is a real-time solver that uses Camus (Previti and Marques-Silva 2013) instead of camus (Liffiton and Sakallah 2008) to calculate a subset of MUSes. In fact, eMUS is a real-time solver that outperforms Camus when dealing with partial MUSes enumeration.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we examined a new framework for characterizing inconsistencies based on the proposed independent decomposition property and MUS decomposition. Such defined inconsistency measures (e.g. I ′ M and ID) are presented with desired properties. Distributable MUS decomposition allows inconsistencies to be resolved in parallel, which is a rarely considered methodology for handling large knowledge bases with important information. Complexity and practical algorithms are examined based on the progress of the MUS enumeration. We will investigate the lower complexity of the measure and examine future applications of the proposed methodology.
